title: Who is the most under-appreciated musical artist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Micheal Kiwanuka.  (From one of his music videos) It’s hard to talk/write about good music, you kind of have to… well, listen too it. But I’ll try my best. If you’ve never heard of Kiwanuka, he’s a British musician born to Ugandan parents and raised in London. His debut studio album Home Again was released in 2011, and he’s continued creating amazing music ever since.  Even if you’ve never heard his name it’s very possible that you’ve heard his songs. Some of his more cinematic pieces have been used movies and TV such as: Big Little LiesThe Get DownWhen they see usAtlantaShamelessKiwanuka spent his early years taking gigs as a session guitarist, even backing up Adele on her 2011 tour. One of Kiwanuka's first songs to get international attention was Love and Hate, the title track for an album that included many other beautiful songs such as One More Night, Black Man In A White World, and Cold Little Heart.  If these sound like melancholy titles, it’s because some of them are. But, the creativity, originality, and just overall feel of his music is actually insane. Anyway, I’m bad at words, so I’ll paste some quotes from people who are famously good at words, Music Critics and YouTube Commenters: “Psychedelic soul… gospel rock reminiscent of Marvin Gaye, The Rolling Stones, Hendrix” -The Telegraph “Timeless and contemporary” - The Guardian “That feeling when your nostalgic for a time before you were born” - YouTube commenter “Brilliant, damn Brilliant” - YouTube commenter “Stumbled on one of his songs around midnight it’s now 3am and I’m still going strong lol” - YouTube commenter “The kind of song you will search for, and feel pure satisfaction when you find it” - YouTube commenter I could go on, but you get the point. If you haven’t already cued up one of his playlists… cmon what are you doing with your life?  ∆∆∆

This little list is quite personal. You’re invited to take it or leave it. Lowell George. Nominal leader of Little Feat from 1970 to ‘79, he was a songwriter, singer, guitarist and producer. Little Feat released a string of albums that were critically acclaimed but they never quite hit it big. Sadly, ol’ Lowell died young due, at least in part, to his penchant for self-abuse. Jimmy Page once said in an interview that Feat was his favorite American band. High praise indeed. Here’s a good example of his songwriting, singing and guitar playing skills (on slide). It also showcases what a tight band Little Feat was.  Valerie Carter. A virtual unknown who released a couple of dynamite albums in the late ’70s that passed under the radar. “A Stone’s Throw Away” (1977) is a forgotten gem. On it she’s backed up by Little Feat and the White Brothers from Earth, Wind and Fire among others. This cover of “Ooh Child” shows her in fine form. Coming out of the break she really lets loose. But she wouldn’t play the industry games and so never got the recognition she deserved. Valerie recently passed on and it’s a bit sad that few noted the event. We lost a truly excellent singer.  Jim Carroll. A lot of people liked the movie “The Basketball Diaries”. But few of those who saw it know who Jim Carroll is, even though the movie was about him. In 1980 he and his band released “Catholic Boy”, a punk rock album with all the energy and angst of the genre, but with tight song construction and lyrics that weren’t just angry, but literary. Carroll went on to become a sort of “Street Poet Laureate” for New York City. “People Who Died” is a punk anthem few other songs in the genre could match.
